reviewText: Like" Just Me "bvd"" I'm an Alan Rickman fan, and "Truly Madly Deeply" is one of my top ten favorites, but I was interested in this both because I'm a Colin Firth fan and loved the original film with Michael Caine, Shirley MacClaine & Herbert Lom. They are both light films but I like this version better, which I bought in region 2 format from Amazon UK. Will probably buy the US version as well. Funny and quite different from the original -- Caneron Diaz is a rodeo cowgirl from Texas and Alan Rickman a ruthless businessman who likes to work nude and has a cat shaved to look like a lion with a mane and tuft at the end of its tail. Colin Firth is hilarious and still gorgeous after all these years, and it was a treat to see Tom Courtney ( The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner ) as his co-conspirator.

The secret's out. I'm a Die Hard Alan Rickman fan! I buy every movie i can find with him in it; from the Harry Potter series to the lesser known Closet Land (PAL Format). This film, Gambit, lies somewhere in between. It"s an "ok" film. Alan has more of a supporting role here. Colin Firth and Cameron Diaz take the leads. I knew this before buying the dvd, so i wasn't disapointed. I'll leave the more detailed and wordy reviews of the story line to other folk. They do it much better than i. Gambit is not one of the films i have in my Rickman collection that i will watch again and again. For that i go to Truly Madly Deeply, a GREAT girl-flick and Rasputin: Dark Servant of Destiny. He won an award for his performance here and justly deserved, too. Check it out. AMAZING! Bottom line: GAMBIT is a good film to pass the time with and just for the fun of it, Alan once again exposes HIS "bottom line". Tastefuly! Of course.
Love this movie. Makes a nice caper double-feature night when combined with "How to Steal A Million" (Audrey Hepburn).
Fun film. Didn't think thathat Diaz and Firth would be good together but it worked.

Colin just kills in this movie and Cameron is just adorable. This movie is just too perfect.  I cannot decide which of the many scenes are funnier:  Colin trying to explain that he wants to see a rodeo to find PJ  or him getting caught in the cat / lion alarm system(where cameron has to save him of course) is the best part!  I love them all.
Great cast...but disappointed in movie..expected more...just an OK..
No
Potentially hilarious material, but falls completely flat, despite a cast of brilliant actors. Writers and director failed us - hey guys, what happened?
GOOD MOVIE
Loved this movie (with the exception of Cameron  Diaz's horrible Texas accent!). The ending was a total surprise!!
Very funny with a nice twist.

My god, this is the funniest movie I've seen in years! Subtle tongue in cheek humor and Alan Rickman is a magnificent movie-stealer as always. Not a fan of Cameron Diaz but Colin Firth is also wonderfully humourous.

Sturgeon's Law (paraphrased) states "90% of fiction, music, art and films is of low quality". The Cohen Brothers have a pretty good track record with more than 50% of their offerings residing in the elite 10% of "good material". However, when good filmmakers miss the strike zone, they tend to hit the batter. In this case, the batter is the audience, and the Cohen brothers, despite good intentions, pitched one right at the head missing the strike zone by a mile. "Gambit", a throwback to the caper comedies popular in the 1960's with the likes of Audrey Hepburn and Cary Grant, is a good idea with a good cast wasted on a poorly written script. The "funny parts" weren't funny, and I couldn't take the serious parts seriously. The most entertaining parts are the cartoon intro, a common device of 1960's films of this ilk, and a couple of flash-back and flash-forward scenes. From there it goes downhill.

The central premise, decent but its script needed a lot more rewrites, involves the hustling of a billionaire magnate out of millions by selling him a fake painting. Harry Deane (Colin Firth) is a disgruntled art-curator seeking to outwit his vain employer, billionaire Lord Lionel Shabandar (Alan Rickman), out of millions of pounds. Lord Lionel has a weakness for Monet paintings, particularly the ones featuring haystacks. Deane solicits the help of The Major (Tom Courtenay) who can replicate paintings by the best modern masters. Before the events of the story, we learn the Major has faked a Monet. Now they need a hook to entice their prey.

They find a pretty young woman, PJ Puznowski (Cameron Diaz), a cowgirl rodeo enthusiast in Texas, and create a narrative in which her family has supposedly owned a real Monet for many years. Deane and the Major find her at a bar in Texas, and she agrees to engage in the deception for a fee of 500,000, or about $800,000 US. For the con to work, they take a picture of PJ and her mother sitting on an old 1970's couch in a caravan/mobile home which is then published in a rodeo magazine, which happens to be one of Lord Lionel's many publications. There's a short sequence in which Deane and the Major imagine how the con will play out successfully before they return the current "time" in which they need to convince PJ.

She agrees, and then Deane shows the magazine photo to Lord Lionel who believes the painting only to be a replica because of its residing in a mobile home (called a "caravan" in British English) in Texas. Deane convinces him they should at least explore the possibility the painting is real, and they fly PJ to London. PJ meets Lionel, but rather to Deane's horror, PJ takes a liking to Lord Lionel and begins having doubts about engaging in the deception. Back at his flat, Deane keeps getting punched out by his neighbor. Is this supposed to be funny? Also, we learn Deane is nearly tapped out, being forced to pay extravagant prices for PJ's accommodations at the Savoy Hotel in London, one of the most expensive in Europe.

Lord Lionel then asks PJ on a dinner date at a Japanese Restaurant where they meet the Kon'nichiwa Media Club who are there to interpret Japanese for the English-speaking guests. Up until now, some of the humor was barely tolerable and I wanted the story to get on track about the con. However, the Cohen Brothers opted for nearly-offensive stereotyping of Japanese people I guess for cheap laughs. Then Deane finds a priceless vase in the hallway of the hotel and tries to pilfer it by risking his life on the hotel ledge. Couldn't he have just stuffed it into a suitcase? I found the rest of the film going from hard-to-watch to nearly-insufferable.

You have to credit the three leads for doing the best they could with a mediocre script. Rickman makes an excellent multi-zillionaire as PJ calls him, Firth a good straight-man to Diaz and Rickman, and Diaz as the clueless southern American who knows nothing about British/European culture. Unfortunately, there were too many over-the-top moments which I guess were designed to be funny but more in the "you can't be serious" department. Deane literally losing his pants to steal the vase was one of many. Also, I wasn't quite buying that Deane was "tapped out". I was expecting something at the beginning, maybe a sequence with him and Rickman in which he's denied a raise or similar denial for loyal service. Also, I started to find Firth's character annoying as the film progressed rather than rooting for him to take his employer to the cleaners. Unfortunately, the Cohen brothers missed the strike zone on this one and ended up in Sturgeon's 90%. What a bummer.
Loved Alan Rickman.  Diaz was bad.  Firth turned out just a common their.  At first I thought it really about how he was treated by Rickman.  Did not like that outcome.
Cute movie. Great to see Colin Firth and Alan Rickman playing against each other. Cameron Diaz was brilliant as well.
Forgettable fun. Acting is great, storyline anything but believable.

This is the only time I have EVER given a Colin Firth movie a 3. But the overall feel of this movie (to me) is cartoon-wish. Carrmin Diaz is god awful at trying to be a southern gal and Colin Firth seems disheveled and fragmented.
Stupid, predictable story, bad acting. What more can I say?
Well you might have to know a bit about art and the differences in Proper British English verses Texas American... woo doggies! to really enjoy this.
I want every movie that Colin Firth is in!! I thought it was right up there with the Michael Caine original version...
Great!

British guy seems to live a life where nothing really goes his way. He is constantly knocked around both verbally and physically. He soldiers on without losing his temper. So he comes up with a plan to cheat his mean "boss" out of millions of dollars over a painting. It involves going to TX and getting a girl from a small town to participate in his con game. Nothing goes his way from the get-go.

There are some funny pieces. Very stiff British humor. Some just stupid (to me as an American) parts. There are of course the stereotypes of Texans and small town Americans, as well as Brits that really is getting old and outdated. But there is a funny scene where he is in TX, in a bar, ready to proposition the Cameron character with his scheme. It is basically the entire movie/plot played out in the Firth's character's head. Then he snaps to reality and you get to see how it "really" plays out. Sorta funny.
Waste of time.  Insipid.  Couldn't finish.
Great movie, fun, wonderful cast!
Nothing too special - funny, well acted, but,,,,,
It came just as it was described.
This is very very good to me. I love it very much!
Funny and kept my attention

I expected so much more from this video after I saw the ads for it.  It was kind of lame even Colin Firth, Cameron Diaz and Alan Rickman could not save it.  I love Colin Firth and really expected more of him.  So far I have loved all of Cameron Diaz' movies but this one was a dud. Alan Rickman was wonderful in Sense and Sensibility, even Love, Actually but not in this one.  I don't think I want to recommend this movie because I still have not figured out what it was about!!
Ok
Terrible
very good
Terrible. Could not even finish watching it. Turned it off mid movie.
Fair warning the movie discription/sinopsis has nothing to to with the actual movie.

I spend a nice, relaxing moment watching this very honest comedy, even if it is not any kind of masterpiece. Below, more of my impressions, with some LIMITED SPOILERS.

British art curator Harry Deane (Colin Firth) works for a morbidly rich and horribly abusive man, media mogul Lord Lionel Shabandar (Alan Rickman). After years of suffering he decides to take revenge on his boss, by using his one Achilles heel - Monet. Indeed Shabandar is obsessed with Monet's paintings and especially he was hunting for years and years for a little known piece known as "Haystacks at Dusk", which was plundered by Goering in 1940, but vanished since 1945. To succeed Deane teams up with a master art forger known as the Major (Tom Courtenay) and a rodeo girl from Texas, a certain PJ Puznowski (Cameron Diaz), the granddaughter of American sergeant who supposedly was the last man to see the painting in 1945... The plan is to sell a supposedly miraculously found painting to Shabandar for a ridiculous amount of money... Of course, no plan survives intact the first moments of battle and therefore from the beginning virtually everything will go wrong...))) That covers the first two minutes of the film and then the story really begins.

This is the remake of a 1966 comedy under the same title with Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine. I admit with some shame that I didn't see this film and therefore I cannot compare them - but this 2012 remake was quite entertaining and well done.

All the four main actors did really very well and once Stanley Tucci appears, in a couple of short but significant cameos, he is absolutely irresistible too...))) The scenario for this 2012 version was written by Coen brothers and you can instantly feel it, as characters are well worked out, dialogs are quite good and jokes are funny. There is only one scene in which the humour flies a little bit lower (it involves an embarassing wet spot on the pants of one of the characters) but it is not a very long one. There is no obscenities and nothing gross - in fact the film is so dignified, that one lonely f@rt joke sounds with nobility of a national anthem...))) There are also some rather surprising twists and the ending is not bad at all.

Summa summarum I liked this film, I laughed a lot and I spend a nice relaxing moment watching it. I may even keep the DVD for another viewing in the future. ENJOY!

This is actually a pretty good movie.  My wife made me watch it with her.  My expectation was very low but the movie is actually funny and interesting to watch.  There is nothing like spending quality time with your spouse to share a few laughters together in a evening after dinner.  This is probably one of the best Cameron Diaz movies I have seen.
Good vehicle for great cast.
I don't appreciate nudity!
Loved this movie!

Cute movie.  Cameron Diaz is a hoot and blends nicely with always a little uptight Colin Firth.  He handles the comedy well, but this is her film.  No one can portray the smartest ditz in the room like Cameron.  Only one previous actress had the ability, Goldie Hawn.  Others have tried but these two are the champs.
Funny and weird.  Colin Firth with no pants on (coat, shirt and tie ok), Alan Rickman starkers (what would Dumbledore say), but Tom Courtenay kept his clothes on for once.
Love this movie! It's hilarious! I bought it because of Alan Rickman, and as usual he doesn't disappoint.
First class fun.
A good movie all told. I like Colin Firths movies yet his co star isn't a favorite. They worked well together however in this film.
love Colin Firth and this movie delivers has its twists of best plans made
Love this movie. Qucik-witted dialogue. Great acting. LOL funny.
Colin Firth is hilarious in a Peter Sellers-like role; Cameron Diaz is appealing; Alan Rickman acts with his mouth.  Several plot twists.

If you really want to see what this movie could have been (and was) watch the original Gambit with Shirley MacLaine and Michael Caine. That version was so fine it isn't surprising that a decision was made to remake it, but unfortunately this ultimately proved to be a very bad decision ... particularly in light of the script and the decision to cast Cameron Diaz. There is a reason it was never released in the USA but went straight to DVD here.
Awful - extremely forced performances.
this was a fun remake of Michael Cain's Movie. I thought this funnier, but Herber Lom made a better villian
Watched 5 minutes :( could not get into it at all.
I had to quit about 1/2 way. Snooze fest.
A laugh a minute.  Silly British humour, if you like that kind of thing.
ok
Good plot though the acting is a bit over the too for these talented actors, especially Stanley Tucci, who seems to be just having fun with a really bad German accent.
Really great and funny movie.  I would watch it again!

"Gambit" could be fun, but it's just a tad too chaotic to be truly enjoyable.

 I'll watch anything with either Alan Rickman or Colin Firth, but this one just doesn't work in spite of their efforts. It is, however, just about what you'd expect from a Cameron Diaz movie.

I expected a good movie given that Colin Firth and the actor who plays Snape on Harry Potter was there. However this movie was a  disappointment.  The story was okay, I think there was potential to make a much funnier movie than the one they made using the same story line.  The script was not creative.  The fake southern accent from Cameron Diaz made me cringe.  I failed to laugh pretty much during the entire movie.  I kept on hoping it would get better and that the funny bits were yet to come.  But it was the same throughout.  Not worth watching.
great thanks

I loved this comedy - was a very pleasant diversion.  I liked the actors and their silly way of dealing with their issues... It would make a great series, and leaves itself open to future movies or a TV series or mini series... Fun and great acting and scenery.
Plot not too original--uses devices similar to previous movies I've seen, but I like the actors and it's a fun flick.

An uneven but entertaining art heist film based on the classic 60's adventure starring Shirley MacLaine and Michael Caine.  This one, with Colin Firth, Alan Rickman, and Cameron Diaz has moments of inspiration and downright lunacy- most courtesy of the amiable Firth and the comically menacing Rickman.  Ms. Diaz gives a buffoonish turn to the Texan "socialite", which comes close to sinking the ship in a sea of cartoonish overacting and bad accents.

However, the dialogue and pacing is top notch with Stanley Tucci nearly stealing the picture as a bombastic German art curator.  One wishes he had a more significant presence in the film.

Overall a funny, delightful, light caper comedy with solid performances by Rickman, Firth and Tucci.
I'm a huge Colin Firth fan. Love him in Bridgette jones. This movie was just ok- not his greatest work. I think it was the script and co star more Than anything he personally did.
It was a great rental.  Colin Firth is fabulous - as always.
Surprising!
great
great

We thought this was even better than the original.  They used the 'opening gambit' from the original, and improved on it (well, ok, nothing could improve on Shirley MacLaine's stunning dress).  In fact, we thought every modification made this a better movie.  Excellent acting, great original plot twists, wonderful comic bits sprinkled throughout.
Fun
funny as always alan and colin did superb acting

I rented the Gambit movie from redbox at a cheap price while simultaneously unsure of how much I would enjoy it.  Much to my surprise, the film was even better than I thought. This film centers around an art dealers attempts to sell a fake painting to a very wealthy businessman. He feels justified in doing this because of the businessmans ruthless nature. However, from my perspective,the film plays with the question of does two wrongs really make a right?, and that people are not often how they appear on the outside (cant always judge a book by its cover adage). Alan Rickman, Colin Firth, Stanley Tucci, and Cameron Diaz star in The Gambit movie.
Story did not really go anywhere. But it was a fun watch. We got a few chuckles.
Colin Firth is a master!  This movie has great depth in every aspect of movie making!  I've watched it 3 times and am still entertained
Despite its first-rate cast, this is a very bad movie.
Terrible, awful movie!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Fun movie!

Such a funny movie!!! Alan Rickman and Colin Firth are my two favorite actors, so of course I had to buy this. Even my husband (who gets tired of my Alan Rickman obsession) watched it with me and loved it.
Enjoyable movie
I generally like all the actors in this movie, but overall it wasn't funny, entertaining or believable.  Sad for such a talented cast.

I was sure that this could not be done as well as the original- but this proved to be a cute screwball comedy for our time.

Firth is terrific as a stuffy, nerdy man who is fed up with being stepped on by his  arrogant, unappreciative boss.

Diaz is Firth's ticket to revenge against that boss.

What ensues is crazy antics and hilarity. Quick paced movie that leaves you with a smile on your face.

Harry Deane (Colin Firth) wants to scam his boss Lionel (Alan Rickman) for no other reason than Lionel is not a nice man. He employes the help of Texan PJ (Cameron Diaz) to help him with the scam that runs into problems.

The film is reminiscent of a 60's style comedy. The main problem was Diaz's character whose accent and sayings were more cringe worthy than funny. The film makes good use of showcasing Diaz's gams, but outside of that, her character fell flat.

It is a comedy worth a view if you are looking for something amusing which doesn't require you to think too hard. I personally find "The Brothers Broom" a far superior scam flick.

Parental Guide: No f-bombs or sex. Diaz bra/panties. "Partial nudity" means Rickman's butt.
Funny! It had bad reviews, so I had low expectations, and was pleasantly surprised at how funny it was. Loved the lion part!
Boring, too long, not very well thought plot. If you expected movie that you totally dive in and forget about the world for 2h, you will be disappointed

Thought this movie would be a loser but pleasantly it was not. It turned out to be quite fun and both Colin and Cameron sold their parts well. The story line did take a twist that actually was unexpected which was a delight.
The story was very predictable and flat.  There were no sparks between the characters at all. Not worth the time or money.
Was not able to play the film and yet Amazon charged me. the full rental fee without contacting me to offer a refund.

Why do people make remakes of perfectly wonderful movies?? In this remake there is No chemistry between the stars, it is a dull, lifeless clone of the original. Watch the original with Shirley Maclaine and Michael Caine instead.

In the movie Gambit an art curator  (Firth) decides to seek revenge on his abusive boss (Alan Rickman) by conning him into buying a fake Monet, but his plan requires the help of an eccentric and unpredictable Texas rodeo queen (Cameron Diaz)

Gambit actually surprised me a bit as I didn't really expect much from the movie when I rented it but I do like Diaz and decided to give it a watch.  The movie has some funny moments in it (especially the hotel scenes) and was actually funnier than I expected.  Although the humor is a bit uneven in its execution.  It is almost a bit Pink Panther-ish in its style and dry British wit.  Firth, Rickman and Diaz are ok in their roles but I thought that Diaz was a bit over the top at times with her Texas accent and mannerisms.

Overall though, the movie was entertaining enough to watch and had just enough funny bits to keep me amused all the way through.
I love movies, and I really like both of the actors, but I just could not finish it. It was horrible, and Diaz's over-the-top Texas accent was annoying. I'd pass on it, it's not even worth a rental.

The movie has a great cast and a fun storyline but it was a bit flat and disappointing for having such good actors. It's worth a watch and you need to watch to the very end as that's when the surprise is. I'd rate it a PG-13 (which is its rating) movie as there is a fairly long shot of Cameron Diaz in her underwear and another shot of Alan Rickman in the buff though nothing is shown of his front groin and the most is a butt shot. Just a warning for those looking for family fare. So a fun whimsical movie that was ok and had some good moments.

Stay away from this one. What can I say? With a cast that includes Colin Firth, Cameron Diaz, Alan Rickman, Stanley Tucci, Julian Rhind-Tutt, and an unrecognizable Tom Courternay, I figured it had to be good......actually, it might have been decent if Diaz hadn't had twenty double espressos, and then been told she's very funny and that she needed to be even funny.......and totally failed. I laughed out loud once.....at a fart joke. I had no idea that the Coen Brothers wrote this, but now I realize, they were getting back to their 'Ladykillers' roots, which is a huge mistake. It takes a lot for a movie to really piss me off. This did, not least because it was so boring, it took me a couple of sessions to watch it, costing me an extra day from Redbox. It was seriously not worth the $2.40 I paid.

Any movie with Cameron Diaz is one that I purchase. This film has a little bit of a serious side, with a really good message. The movie is a sleeper for sure. Can't wait for the Summer 2014 theatrical release of Cameron's next comedy, Sex Tape (due out mid July).

It was a movie that was not a total waste of time. On a movie night, it would be a good back up, or one to have at a party in the background. It had funny moments, and the storyline was entertaining. The actors did a really great job, so that fact made it more enjoyable, than it could have been if lesser actors had the roles. Overall, not bad :)

Art (or jewelry, etc.) theft movies have appeared in endless permutations since the dawn of movies and usually a twist redeems most of them. Thus is true in this case. For humor we have the usual hook of American crudeness in counterpoint to British decorum with their touch of snobbery. Additional humor in a slapstick sort of way e.g. getting locked in a closet then escaping by walking on a ledge; appearing in an swank hotel without your pants.

Movie was as karaoke as one of it's karaoke scenes. Unlike the recent "The Best Offer" and to some extent "The Art of the Steal" it had the feel of a quickly put together plot analogous to a quickly put together fake painting.

The story could have had better writer but Colin et el  worked hard t bring it off.  I was hoping for a better relationship between Colin Firth and Cameron Diaz it would have made it more interesting.  No one makes love like Mr. Darcy.

Three of my sons and I were part of the Rodeo crowd scene at the beginning of the movie. If we paused the movie, we could actually see one of my boys sitting on the fence in the background. Fun.
Because of that and because we love most of the actors in this movie. We were sad that it didn't make it to theaters but after seeing it, it wasn't spectacular. Colin Firths character was really funny and the movie was enjoyable to watch.

Laughed all the way through this movie.....
Great acting...The twist at the end was not anticipated but, made it interesting to watch!

Gambit is a remake of the 1966 Michael Caine/Shirley MacLaine caper film. The new version, directed by Joel and Ethan Coen, updates the story to contemporary Texas and England. Harry Deane (Colin Firth) and PJ Puznowski (Cameron Diaz) join forces to trick Harrys bully of a boss, rich British art collector Lionel Shahbandar (Alan Rickman), into buying a Monet fake by a skilled forger (Tom Courtenay).

Everything that can go wrong, does, in a series of farcical episodes involving Harrys comic humiliations. The major flaw is the lack of chemistry between Firth and Diaz. They often seem to have wandered in from other movies. Firth tries hard but never gets into the proper groove. He looks uncomfortable and seems a poor fit for the farcical situations. Ms. Diaz looks beautiful as always but lacks any iota of subtlety in her performance.

There are no bonus extras on the Blu-ray release.

"There are moments in a life that define a man, this was Mr. Deane's. He was sprung for action and yet perfectly capable of blowing it completely." Harry Deane (Firth) is an art curator who is tired of his boss' attitude. He is mean and abusive and needs to be taught a lesson. Harry decides on a plan that involves his boss buying a fake Monet painting form someone he knows and taking the money. He just needs someone to play the person with the painting. When he sees PJ Puznowski (Diaz) all the pieces have fallen into place now all he has to worry about is putting it into action. That is the hard part. This is a funny movie but it isn't for everyone. The humor is British and this has the feel of a less slapstick Pink Panther type movie. Colin Firth is funny in this but I'm not really sure how I felt about Cameron Diaz. Alan Rickman really plays the bad guy role perfectly. As for the movie I liked it and laughed quite a bit but I can see how some people may not like it. This is not a main stream comedy and is really geared for fans of off beat British Comedy. I am a huge fan of heist movies and this one did nothing to change that. Overall, fans of the original Pink Panther movies will like this, it will be hit or miss with everyone else. I did really like it though. I give this a B.

This is a fun movie but not great.  It's a little bit of a throw back style comedy.  The summary on amazon does not describe the movie well.  Go to a movie review web site for better synopsis.  You have to like Colin Firth and Cameron Diaz to enjoy this movie.  The plot twist at the end is great.  DTD

A miss mosh of  events with redundant scenes especially
painful when Alan Rickman was the subject.  It's
difficult to understand why such accomplished actors would be motivated
to make this movie.

Review concerns the streaming quality of the film, which was enjoyable. Unwatchable due to very poor streaming quality of the SD version of film. Constantly stopped for "loading" every few minutes. My TV is an older one, so I choose the SD version instead of the HD version. I ended up renting the HD version as well just to be able to watch the movie and this version worked fine on my TV.
 So choose HD version even if you have an older TV....worked fine with HD but I found out the hard way after having to rent both versions.

I'd like to add that Amazon did give me a refund for the SD rental, which was great of them.

We enjoyed this movie.  While not a movie that we will watch again and again, it was an enjoyable Saturday night.

The story line is about an art curator (Colin Firth) who wants to con his obnoxious wealthy employer (Alan Rickman). He has an accomplice create a forgery of a famous work and recruits a Texas cow girl (Cameron Diaz) to act as the owner.  The con does not go as planned and comedy ensues.  The third act has some fun surprises and twists.

It is one of those movies that could be great but missed the mark.  The movie had some really funny scenes and others that were just awkward.  The cast was great with Diaz's performance being the weak spot.

Gambit is a mildly diverting time waster that I've been waiting to see for a while because of the names of its two writers prominently attached to its marketing. Sure Gambit isn't a Coen Brothers film per se, but the presence of Colin Firth and Alan Rickman doing their best to be funny almost hides the unfortunate anchor keeping it from being something you'll remember long after watching.
I've never seen the original Gambit so unlike The Italian Job or True Grit I don't have that bias holding me back from liking the film. As it goes Gambit is a mildly humorous film driven by stoic Colin Firths unfortunate ability to be a goof ball mucking up what He sees as the best made plans. Using the presence of an American Rodeo star He plans to con his boss into buying a forged painting thought lost to the ages from Nazi plundering. Thats the gist of the story told in an amazingly short time, something to hold in regard in this age where every film seems to need to push the two hour boundary.
Then again this isn't A Serious Man, or even Raising Arizona. It is also thankfully not The Ladykillers, finding the right tone and carrying it through several setups to the finale earning some chuckles along the way. The appeal of Rickman and Firth go a long way in to providing humor to the story. Firth plays the hapless Harry Deane well creating a character who's not willing to admit defeat even when his actions are creating more and more chaos in his reality. Theres a long sequence I particularly liked in the middle of the film that Firth just plays right where He's stuck in hotel, trying to escape a laundry room without pants. Its silly but the way Firth handles every obstacle was funny to me.
Rickman on the other hand plays that Alan Rickman character very, very well as an egotistical millionaire boss, One of the clever things about the role is the way its meant to subvert our view every so often, from the opening sequence which is changed in a twist, to his flirtations with Diaz. This is like the melding of Professor Snape and Hans Gruber played by an actor having fun.
Less fun is the one thing that felt wrong in Cameron Diaz. I'm not one of those people who hate Ms. Diaz as an actress but to me compared to Rickman and Firth her P.J. Puznowski is too broad a performance, ill fitting in the role. From the accent to the way she dresses Diaz was a performer trying to be funny without the grace to actually make me laugh which is a shame. But then again in an eighty minute movie its not a terrible flaw especially when Firth and Rickman are doing the heavy lifting with their characters.
In the end Gambit won't be remembered a year from now. Its not a great comedy but its a fun movie for that hour and a half that entertained me despite its problems.
Great cast phoning it in and cashing the check.  Horribly predictable script.....overall tacky remake of so many charming 60's light comedies. Did not work.

Gambit isn't one of those movies that just lists big stars that you love but isn't really that great. The plot delivers from start to finish, the jokes deliver from start to finish and the actors are great as always. It's not often we laugh so hard that we have to stop the movie. We usually only do that with a few famous sitcoms out there. But we had stopped this movie numerous times to finish giggling or laughing! That just doesn't happen very often.

You cannot figure out the end by the start of the movie, the jokes are extremely witty and sly, understated and performed exactly right. Alan Rickman, Colin Firth and Cameron Diaz are awesome. You didn't want anyone else in each role. It's perfect. We don't enjoy a lot of movies these days. The smart, dry and hysterical humor, like the kind you have to catch in Shakespeare plays (no this isn't Shakespeare) is here. If you love pitch perfect, well done acting that doesn't rely on goofing around or bathroom jokes, here's your movie. Finally!
This film is a disgrace to both Colin Firth and Alan Rickman.  Unbelievably bad plot, writing, etc. I was shocked that such talented actors would be involved in such tripe.

this is a very well done comedic caper, with brightly outlined characters that are superbly cast (firth, courtenay, diaz and rickman), plenty of funny business (the scene in the savoy where diaz and firth quibble in perfect deadpan over the merits of "the little major" had me in tears with laughter), and the several plot twists were just absurd enough to recharge the comedy without destroying the fantasy. the film opens with a beautiful long sequence, the launching and execution of the caper in its entirety -- which involves the sale of a fake monet painting (the work of a talented forger, courtenay), purportedly owned by a texas cowgirl (diaz) to a bullying billionaire (rickman). this turns out to be a daydream of the caper mastermind (firth). the actual caper is then portrayed in humorous contrast, one miscue or impediment after another. several unexpected complications throw the plot into full improvisation, and as the final twist, in the last scene, we discover that we haven't understood the caper at all. it's all very cleverly put together, and the comedic chemistry among the actors is delightful.

as a diehard coen brothers fan, i have to mention this quirk: the screenplay is by the coen brothers but is "mise en scne" by michael hoffman. if you know the coen brothers movies, the effect is uncanny. at some points you can see the coen visual humor blossom on the screen -- for example, the texas mobile home, the blustery femininity of the texas cowgirl, the natty demeanor of the art forger. but other scenes, such as the prolonged shenanigans in the savoy hotel, seem cut from a late ernst lubitsch caper. this puts a peculiar burden on colin firth as the caper mastermind, who must get punched in the face like nicholas cage in "raising arizona" but look unflappably suave with no pants on running around the savoy hotel. the good news is that firth is quite good at striking the balance ("did you say, room *thirteen* eighteen?") and the comedy amalgam of coen and lubitsch is great fun to watch.

This wasn't a bad movie but it wasn't a particularly fun caper film either a la The Italian Job or the like.

It's worth a rental but keep your expectations low and you will probably enjoy it more.
I am a big Colin Firth fan, so may be biased, but I thought this movie was great fun.  Firth has impeccable dry comic wit and timing, and that alone is worth the watch!

A loose remake of the classic Sixties film starring Michael Caine and Shirley Maclaine, GAMBIT is a highly entertaining romp involving Colin Firth as a hapless master-criminal, Cameron Diaz as a rodeo specialist and Alan Rickman as a boorish bourgeois financier, supported by Tom Courtenay as a retired general acting as the narrator for the whole film.  Filmed on location in and around London, it proves quite unexpectedly funny: Firth demonstrates a particular talent for comedy, simply by remaining straight-faced, while Diaz has great fun in an unexpected piece of casting.  The plot is gossamer-thin, involving the creation of a fake painting which Caine hopes to sell to Rickman; what matters more is that the plan keeps going wrong.  There are some memorable set-piece scenes here, notably Firth's parading up and down the halls of London's chic Savoy Hotel without his pants, or Diaz's untuneful karaoke rendition of "The Yellow Rose of Texas" in front of a group of Japanese business people.  The Coen Brothers' script contains several hommages to the Sixties, while moving the action along at a great lick.  Definitely a film to watch if you're feeling down.

Colin Firth, Cameron Diaz, and Alan Richman are excellent in this clever film that reminded me of films like Charade made in the 1960s. The plot has enough twists and turns to keep the viewer on their toes. Colin Firth is an excellent actor and here he downplays or dead-pans his expression when he is repeatedly caught in outrageous and embarrassing situations. Cameron Diaz has a challenging role to play as a Texas rodeo star who lives in a trailer with her mother. She camps it up with absolutely no seriousness in a single line she speaks and she comes off as a great sport. Alan Richman also gets to act outrageously as a billionaire art collector who is beyond rude to everyone around him. There are some similarities to the Michael Caine and Shirley MacLaine film of the same name but there are character and plot differences along with witty dialogue from the Coen brothers that makes this film more than a remake. Is there anything serious about the film? Absolutely nothing. It is clever, outrageous, and witty from start to finish.
hilarious and witty
I love Colin Firth but the story wasn't up to par, didn't even finish because I didn't care how things ended.
Cute, has a little intrigue, a little romance, and a lot of humor.
Excellent movie - recommended by a friend and I'm glad I watched it.
A few chuckles. Just a shadow of the original movie. Love the stars. Yawned at the rewritten script. Disappointed in the tacky unnecessary crudeness. Watch the Original.
great
Maybe its just the English humor (which I usually enjoy) but I just couldn't get into this one. Maybe we'll watch it once more to see if it clicks.
The original Gambit movie starring Shirley McLaine & Michael Caine is better.

What a fun movie!  Cameron Diaz absolutely knocks it out of the park with her Southern accent.  If I didn't know whom she was, I would believe her accent to be real.  Colin Firth and others were also quite good.  The plot twisted differently than I thought it would, which was great, because it kept me guessing throughout.  The plot came across as plausible, which really added to the movie's fun, flare, and humor.  I only gave it one star, because I would like to have seen and heard more of Cameron Diaz.  In some scenes she was completely silent while other (men) did all the talking.  Otherwise, what a delightfully enjoyable film!
Love it
